techniques.name: Stakeholder Mapping
techniques.summary: Visualize and prioritize stakeholders based on influence, interest, and proximity to the problem.
techniques.description: Visualize and prioritize stakeholders based on influence, interest, and proximity to the problem.

techniques.name: Empathy Interviews
techniques.summary: Open-ended conversations that reveal users’ emotions, pain points, goals, and workarounds.
techniques.description: Open-ended conversations that reveal users’ emotions, pain points, goals, and workarounds.
techniques.seo_description: Open-ended conversations that reveal users’ emotions, pain points, goals, and workarounds.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Problem Interview Matrix
techniques.summary: Capture and compare problems across different personas to identify shared or distinct needs.
techniques.description: Capture and compare problems across different personas to identify shared or distinct needs.

techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Jobs To Be Done (JTBD)
techniques.summary: Describe what users are trying to accomplish in a broader context.
techniques.description: Describe what users are trying to accomplish in a broader context.
techniques.seo_title: Jobs To Be Done (JTBD) – Discovery & Problem Framing
techniques.seo_description: Describe what users are trying to accomplish in a broader context.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Diary Studies
techniques.summary: Have users log behaviors, decisions, and challenges over time.
techniques.description: Have users log behaviors, decisions, and challenges over time.
techniques.seo_description: Have users log behaviors, decisions, and challenges over time.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Field Research
techniques.summary: Observe users in their natural environment to uncover real-world behaviors and contexts.
techniques.description: Field Research involves direct observation of users in their actual environment, such as homes or workplaces, to understand contextual factors influencing their behavior. It reveals implicit needs, challenges, and habits that users may not verbalize in interviews. This method uncovers environmental and behavioral patterns critical for designing realistic and relevant solutions.
techniques.seo_description: Observe people in their real-world environments.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Service Safari
techniques.summary: Use competitors’ or analogous services firsthand to uncover design insights.
techniques.description: A Service Safari is a hands-on exploration where team members experience competitors’ or related services from a customer perspective. By going through onboarding, shopping, or support processes, teams can identify good practices, gaps, or friction points that inform product design. It fosters empathy and sparks innovation by examining what works — and doesn’t — in the wild.
techniques.seo_description: Use competitor or related services firsthand to understand what works and what doesn’t.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Assumption Mapping
techniques.summary: Identify and prioritize risky assumptions to guide early validation.
techniques.description: Assumption Mapping is a structured way to surface the team’s beliefs about users, product success, or technology. These assumptions are plotted on a 2x2 grid of certainty and risk to prioritize research and testing. It helps prevent building on faulty assumptions and ensures efforts are focused where failure would be most damaging or likely.
techniques.seo_description: Make assumptions explicit and prioritize based on risk and uncertainty.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Opportunity Interviews
techniques.summary: Explore frustrations and unmet needs rather than asking for solutions.
techniques.description: Opportunity Interviews are designed to uncover latent needs by asking about pain points, inefficiencies, and workarounds in users’ routines. The focus is on understanding problems, not on collecting feature requests. This technique surfaces areas of opportunity where innovation can have high impact and avoids solution bias early in the process.
techniques.seo_description: Ask about frustrations, not solutions.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Cultural Probes
techniques.summary: Use creative tools to provoke emotional and contextual insights from users.
techniques.description: Cultural Probes are kits provided to users containing items like journals, stickers, or disposable cameras that invite them to document their experiences creatively. These artifacts reveal emotional, cultural, and environmental influences on behavior. Probes are especially useful in exploring subconscious motivations and gathering rich qualitative data for design inspiration.
techniques.seo_description: Provide creative materials to participants to provoke insights.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Contextual Inquiry
techniques.summary: Observe and question users during real tasks to understand behaviors and challenges.
techniques.description: Contextual Inquiry blends observation and interviewing in the user's environment. Participants perform actual tasks while thinking aloud, and the facilitator probes with questions. This method captures not just what users do, but why — revealing mental models, decision points, and context-specific pain points essential for usable design.
techniques.seo_description: Observe users while asking them to think aloud during real tasks.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Red Route Analysis
techniques.summary: Identify critical tasks that users must complete successfully for the product to deliver value.
techniques.description: Red Route Analysis is used to pinpoint the most important user journeys — the 'red routes' — that should never fail. By mapping and optimizing these high-frequency, high-value tasks, teams can ensure the product is efficient and satisfying for core users. Non-essential features can be deprioritized to avoid clutter and friction.
techniques.seo_title: Red Route Analysis – Discovery & Problem Framing
techniques.seo_description: Identify and optimize the most mission-critical user paths.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Pre-mortem Exercise
techniques.summary: Imagine the product failed and explore what could have gone wrong.
techniques.description: A Pre-mortem is a foresight technique where the team assumes a product has failed, then works backward to identify likely causes. By surfacing risks early, the exercise builds alignment on what to mitigate or monitor. It’s a powerful tool for de-risking bold ideas and ensuring diverse perspectives are considered upfront.
techniques.seo_description: Pretend the product failed — ask 'what went wrong?'
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Signal Sniffing
techniques.summary: Look for weak signals of emerging needs across adjacent channels.
techniques.description: Signal Sniffing involves scanning non-traditional sources — such as forums, social media, or app reviews — for early indicators of user trends, frustrations, or desires. These weak signals can uncover unmet needs before they become mainstream, giving teams a head start on innovation and competitive differentiation.
techniques.seo_description: Look for signals of demand or unmet needs from adjacent spaces.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Discovery & Problem Framing

techniques.name: Design Studio / Crazy 8s
techniques.summary: A collaborative design exercise encouraging rapid ideation through structured sketching, often in time-boxed rounds.
techniques.description: Design Studio, particularly in the Crazy 8s format, is a fast-paced sketching activity where individuals generate eight distinct design ideas in eight minutes. It's designed to encourage divergent thinking and uncover a wide range of solutions before converging on promising ones. Often used at the beginning of a project or feature sprint, this method is ideal for visualizing UI concepts, workflows, or service interactions in a low-fidelity, low-pressure format.
techniques.seo_title: Design Studio / Crazy 8s – Design & Solution Ideation
techniques.seo_description: Rapid sketching by individuals or teams to generate multiple solution ideas quickly.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Story Mapping
techniques.summary: A visual technique to map user activities and break down functionality into slices of user value.
techniques.description: Story Mapping helps teams understand the user journey by organizing user activities and tasks along a timeline of usage. Stories are arranged in layers, with high-level goals at the top and implementation details below. This method supports incremental delivery by identifying vertical slices that deliver usable value, making it easier to prioritize and plan releases. It also highlights dependencies and gaps in user experience.
techniques.seo_description: Visualise the user journey and slice work into high-value increments.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Value Proposition Canvas
techniques.summary: Tool to align customer jobs, pains, and gains with product features and benefits.
techniques.description: The Value Proposition Canvas consists of two parts: the Customer Profile and the Value Map. The Customer Profile outlines the customer’s jobs, pains, and gains. The Value Map matches this with products and services, pain relievers, and gain creators. Teams use this canvas to refine ideas, adjust positioning, and ensure that the offering resonates with customer needs. It’s particularly useful for product-market fit exploration and early-stage product design.
techniques.seo_title: Value Proposition Canvas – Design & Solution Ideation
techniques.seo_description: Align customer pains and gains with product features.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Co-Design Workshops
techniques.summary: Structured sessions that engage users and stakeholders in creating or shaping product ideas together.
techniques.description: Co-design workshops bring users, designers, and other stakeholders into a shared design process. Using props, storyboards, roleplay, or digital tools, participants express needs and imagine solutions collaboratively. These sessions foster empathy, capture real-world language and routines, and generate ideas grounded in user context. They are effective at bridging the gap between design intent and lived experience.
techniques.seo_description: Bring users into collaborative design sessions.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Design Tokens
techniques.summary: Reusable variables that encode the design system (e.g. spacing, color, font) for use across code and tools.
techniques.description: Design tokens are the smallest parts of a design system—such as color values, spacing units, border radii, or font sizes—expressed as variables. They help ensure consistency and scalability across platforms and teams. When integrated into design tools and front-end codebases, tokens allow updates to cascade globally, simplify theming, and reduce UI defects. They support efficient collaboration between designers and developers, especially in large or multi-brand systems.
techniques.seo_description: Standardize colors, spacing, and typography for consistency across components.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Lean UX Canvas
techniques.summary: Single-page plan that articulates user assumptions, hypotheses, and what will be measured.
techniques.description: Single-page plan that articulates user assumptions, hypotheses, and what will be measured.
techniques.seo_title: Lean UX Canvas – Design & Solution Ideation
techniques.seo_description: Single-page plan that articulates user assumptions, hypotheses, and what will be measured.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Storyboarding

techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.description: Test how users naturally organize information.

techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Privacy Personas
techniques.summary: Design with different attitudes toward data sharing in mind.
techniques.description: Design with different attitudes toward data sharing in mind.
techniques.seo_description: Design with different attitudes toward data sharing in mind.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Consent Pattern Mapping
techniques.summary: Explore different ways to offer and manage consent.
techniques.description: Explore different ways to offer and manage consent.
techniques.seo_title: Consent Pattern Mapping – Design & Solution Ideation
techniques.seo_description: Explore different ways to offer and manage consent.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Content Chunking Matrix
techniques.summary: Break down content into digestible, reusable pieces.
techniques.description: Break down content into digestible, reusable pieces.
techniques.seo_title: Content Chunking Matrix – Design & Solution Ideation
techniques.seo_description: Break down content into digestible, reusable pieces.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Design & Solution Ideation

techniques.name: Walking Skeleton
techniques.summary: Build a minimal end-to-end working version of the product to test infrastructure and integration early.
techniques.description: A Walking Skeleton is a minimal, yet complete slice of a system that demonstrates the basic technical infrastructure and integrations. It avoids overengineering up front while enabling the team to test and iterate incrementally with real system constraints. It includes key elements such as user login, data flow, and basic navigation across frontend and backend components.
techniques.purpose: To validate core architecture and integrations by implementing the thinnest viable vertical slice of the product.
techniques.seo_description: Walking Skeleton is a thin end-to-end implementation used to validate architecture, pipelines, and integration in the early stages of development.
techniques.knowledge_categories.name: Delivery & Prototyping

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart MVP Architecture
knowledge_examples.description: The SmartCart team built a walking skeleton that allowed users to register, add one item to their cart, and schedule a delivery — all using real backend services and infrastructure. No advanced features like personalized recommendations or meal planning were included.
knowledge_examples.context: Pre-alpha phase of SmartCart development to validate backend logistics, APIs, and account workflows.
knowledge_examples.outcome: Revealed a gap in delivery scheduling API performance early, prompting optimization before feature scaling.

techniques.name: Concierge MVP
techniques.summary: A manually delivered version of a product to validate demand before investing in full automation.
techniques.description: Concierge MVP is a lean approach where a real human performs the core product functions behind the scenes. It allows teams to test assumptions about value and desirability without committing to costly development upfront. This method is particularly useful for validating complex or behavior-dependent features before automation.
techniques.purpose: To validate the desirability and usefulness of a feature or service by manually simulating the experience before investing in automation.
techniques.seo_title: Concierge MVP - Simulate Product Manually Before Building
techniques.seo_description: Use Concierge MVPs to validate product ideas by simulating the service manually, helping teams learn quickly and reduce risk.

knowledge_examples.title: Manual SmartCart Planning Service
knowledge_examples.description: Before building an automated weekly planning system, SmartCart tested its concept by manually contacting users every Sunday to gather preferences and then curating shopping lists by hand.
knowledge_examples.context: Pre-launch testing of SmartCart's auto-planning features
knowledge_examples.outcome: Validated user interest in automated lists, avoided weeks of engineering rework

techniques.name: Trunk-based Development
techniques.summary: A development practice where all code changes are committed to a single shared branch to encourage rapid integration.
techniques.description: Trunk-based development minimizes integration headaches by having all developers work in short-lived branches or directly on a shared mainline branch. This encourages continuous integration and facilitates better collaboration across frontend, backend, and DevOps teams. It works well in fast-moving teams aiming for frequent releases.
techniques.purpose: To accelerate delivery by integrating work frequently and reducing merge conflicts.
techniques.seo_description: Accelerate software delivery using trunk-based development. Learn how frequent commits and feature toggles improve quality and speed.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart Incremental Smart Basket Release
knowledge_examples.description: SmartCart engineers built the 'Smart Suggestions' feature using trunk-based development with feature toggles to enable safe, incremental rollout.
knowledge_examples.context: Feature delivery on a shared backend across platforms
knowledge_examples.outcome: Faster integration and safer release of experimental features
